moves.1. e4 e5 2. d4: This old-fashioned opening exposes White's Queen to Black's pieces. Black tends to gain an advantage in development as a result.
moves.3... Nc6: Developing the Knight to its natural square and gaining a tempo.
moves.4... Nf6: Now Black can develop his King Knight as well. He has 2 pieces out and White only has 1.
moves.5. Bc4: Overly aggressive. White does need to develop, but a more modest move such as B-Q3 or N-QB3 [both of which also defend the exposed KP] would serve him better. Because of the premature Queen development, White is on the defensive.
moves.5... Ne5: Swiderski takes advantage of White's mistake, centralizing his Knight and attacking the unprotected KB.
moves.6. Bb3: White's Bishop is forced to retreat...
moves.6... Bb4+: ...allowing Swiderski time to develop another piece with tempo. White needs to develop and break the attack. 7 N-QB3 or 7 N-Q2 is in order.
moves.7. c3: A major blunder by White. Not only does this not develop a piece, it also blocks his QN from its natural square!
moves.7... Bc5: Swiderski pounces, attacking the Queen again. Obviously White cannot play 8 QxB??? as 8...N-Q6 ch!!! would fork White's King and Queen. Probably the "best" move is 8 Q-K2, although even then White would be in trouble, massively behind in development.
moves.8. Qg3: The second blunder in a row allows Swiderski a brilliant finish.
moves.8... Bxf2+: Forking King and Queen. If 9 QxB, 9...N-Q6 ch forks the royalty again. If 9 KxB, 9...NxP ch ALSO forks the white royals! White does the honorable thing and resigns. He has been magnificently outplayed!
